descend: Crossing the air‒sea interface; surface tension ripples around you
ascend: Emerging into the spray layer; waves crest above

descend: Epipelagic start: full solar irradiance,  photosynthesis in overdrive
ascend: Returning to the photosynthetic maximum; coral larvae drift nearby

descend: Do you ever wonder what else lies beneath these sunlit shallows?
ascend: Do you ever wonder what else lies beneath these sunlit shallows?

descend: The surface looks calm, but even here the deep starts pulling on you.
ascend: The surface looks calm, but even here the deep starts pulling on you.

descend: You are in the photic zone, where light fuels life.
ascend: You are in the photic zone, where light fuels life.

descend: Most of the world’s lakes are no deeper than this.
ascend: Most of the world’s lakes are no deeper than this.

descend: Pressure here is just beginning to rise. Each 10 meters adds another atmosphere.
Even shallow water can feel endless when you look down.
ascend: Even shallow water can feel endless when you look down.

descend: Light bends and scatters. Colors begin to fade with depth.
The first few meters teem with energy.
ascend: The first few meters teem with energy.

descend: In many lakes, this is the mixing zone where surface and deeper waters swap places.
ascend: In many lakes, this is the mixing zone where surface and deeper waters swap places.

descend: Do you ever wonder what’s under your feet, even when it looks like nothing at all?
ascend: Do you ever wonder what’s under your feet, even when it looks like nothing at all?

descend: Below 30 m, colors begin to vanish. Reds disappear first.
Sunlight only penetrates so far. Darkness is coming.
You're in the epilimnion, the lake's sunlit, churning skin.
ascend: You're in the epilimnion, the lake's sunlit, churning skin.

descend: Shallow water hides more mystery than you think.
ascend: Shallow water hides more mystery than you think.

descend: To most life, these top layers are everything. But you’re going deeper.
It starts here, with a little light, a little pressure, and a lot of questions.
Pressure isn’t much here. But wait.
What’s above you fades out of sight. What’s below… unknown.
ascend: What’s above you fades out of sight. What’s below… unknown.

descend: Pressure is 11 times what it is at sea level. And still rising.
Below this, surface storms have no meaning.
ascend: Below this, surface storms have no meaning.

descend: Some lakes end here. Others keep falling into total darkness.
ascend: Some lakes end here. Others keep falling into total darkness.

descend: You’re crossing layers that rarely mix. Water can stay trapped here for years.
ascend: You’re crossing layers that rarely mix. Water can stay trapped here for years.

descend: Water gets heavier and colder fast. This could be the thermocline.
ascend: Water gets heavier and colder fast. This could be the thermocline.

descend: You're deeper than most lake bottoms now. Welcome to the unknown.
ascend: You're deeper than most lake bottoms now. Welcome to the unknown.

descend: Down here, even light feels tired. Vision narrows. Time slows.
ascend: Down here, even light feels tired. Vision narrows. Time slows.

descend: Some lakes turn anoxic below this point. Oxygen disappears.
ascend: Some lakes turn anoxic below this point. Oxygen disappears.

descend: You’re approaching the bottom of the photic zone.
ascend: You’re approaching the bottom of the photic zone.

descend: You’ve crossed into the mesopelagic. Twilight for the entire ocean.
ascend: You’ve crossed into the mesopelagic. Twilight for the entire ocean.

descend: It feels quiet here. No sound from the surface reaches clearly.
ascend: It feels quiet here. No sound from the surface reaches clearly.

descend: Welcome to the sunlit edge of ocean and land. Life here adapts to both water and air.
ascend: Welcome to the sunlit edge of ocean and land. Life here adapts to both water and air.

descend: Water sloshes, sun shines, and tiny ecosystems spring to life.
ascend: Water sloshes, sun shines, and tiny ecosystems spring to life.

descend: Water and sun mix here. Salinity, temperature, and waves change fast.
ascend: Water and sun mix here. Salinity, temperature, and waves change fast.
Climbing into waters where red wavelengths still reach

descend: Kelp forests thrive here
Surface wave energy now < 5 % of value at 0 m
ascend: Wave‑induced turbulence resumes above

descend: Last reliable SCUBA depth for recreational divers
ascend: Approaching limits of standard SCUBA certification

descend: Nitrogen narcosis risk begins for air‑breathers
You enter some lakes’ thermocline. Temperatures may drop sharply just below
ascend: Crossing up through some lakes' thermocline. Sunlight has warmed the surface again

descend: Some lakes divide here. Cool, dense water settles below the warmer surface
You cross into colder, deeper waters. The warm top layer ends here
ascend: You rise into warmer water. Sunlight’s warmth returns above

descend: In some waters, the ‘thermocline’ begins, a sharp drop in temperature with depth
ascend: Crossing back up through the thermocline, water warms fast above

descend: Crossing into the mesopelagic zone. Light here is less than 1% of the surface

ascent: Crossing into the mesopelagic zone. Light here is less than 1% of the surface

descend: You leave behind most of the sun’s light. The world dims quickly now
In clearer seas, this is where light becomes too faint for most plants to survive

ascend: Photon flux increases ten‑fold between here and the surface

descend: World freedive record (without fins) ~102 m
ascend: Passing the depth of deepest human breath‑hold

descend: Epipelagic→mesopelagic transition begins
ascend: Re‑entering upper mesopelagic

descend: In lakes or coastal waters, chlorophyll–rich layers often peak around here
ascent: In lakes or coastal waters, chlorophyll–rich layers often peak around here
In tropical seas, this often marks the chlorophyll maximum layer
descend: In tropical seas, this often marks the chlorophyll maximum layer
Entering a low‑oxygen zone where life slows. Oxygen may dip < 2 mg/L
ascend: Entering a low‑oxygen zone where life slows. Oxygen may dip < 2 mg/L

descend: Blue light dominates; other colours absorbed
ascend: Polychromatic light slowly returns

descend: Going any deeper, helium blends become necessary in many dives
End of euphotic zone in many temperate seas
ascend: Returning to the euphotic fringe; photosynthesis resumes above

descend: Mesopelagic ‘twilight’ starts below
ascend: Climbing into final metres of epipelagic brightness

descend: Migratory lanternfish school densely at dusk here
ascend: Passing nightly migration path of lanternfish

descend: Sunlight drops below 1%. Photosynthesis is no longer possible here
ascend: Thanks to light, plants may barely survive above this layer

descend: Entering the SOFAR channel. Sound speed hits its minimum here, allowing low-frequency sound to travel far
ascend: Entering the SOFAR channel. Sound speed hits its minimum here, allowing low-frequency sound to travel far

descend: Vertical migrants turn back here at dawn
Bathypelagic ‘midnight zone’ entry; temperature ~4 °C
ascend: Dim twilight just above

descend: Midnight zone: No light reaches here
Bioluminescent predators dominate here
Diel‑vertical‑migrant crustaceans rarely exceed this depth
ascend: Diel‑vertical‑migrant crustaceans rarely exceed this depth

descend: Pressure here is ~120 atm, about the bite pressure of a hippopotamus
ascend: Pressure here is ~120 atm, about the bite pressure of a hippopotamus

descend: Pressure here is ~400 atm, about the bite pressure of a great white shark
ascend: Pressure here is ~400 atm, about the bite pressure of a great white shark

descend: Water cools toward ~4 °C as you enter the lower bathyal zone
Entering abyssal depths. Temperature stabilizes around 2 °C on vast ocean plains
Approaching global mean ocean depth (~3700 m)
Approaching global mean ocean depth (~3700 m)
Bathyal‑abyssal transition; benthic fauna sparse
ascend: Bathyal‑abyssal transition; benthic fauna sparse

descend: Titanic’s bow sits at ~3800 m depth; still deeper ahead
ascend: Approaching depths of historic wrecks

descend: Submarine cables are buried here to mitigate damage
ascend: Submarine cables are buried here to mitigate damage

descend: Passing hydrothermal vent territory. Chimney-like black smokers may rise here
ascend: Passing hydrothermal vent territory. Chimney-like black smokers may rise here

descend: Approaching RMS Titanic resting depth (3800 m)
ascend: Passing the grave of RMS Titanic

descend: Descending into depth where the ROV Nereus met its end (~9,990 m)
ascend: Ascending from the depths where Nereus imploded (~9,990 m)

descend: In 1521, Magellan lowered a line and found no bottom, believing he'd hit the deepest ocean here
ascend: Passing depths where Magellan once thought he'd measured ocean’s bottom (~730 m)

descend: Approaching the depth of Atlantic abyssal plains (~4,600–4,800 m)
ascend: Approaching the depth of Atlantic abyssal plains (~4,600–4,800 m)

descend: Deep‑sea storms may churn sediment here. Strong currents resuspend the seabed
ascend: Deep‑sea storms may churn sediment here. Strong currents resuspend the seabed

descend: Abyss→hadal transition; trench walls appear
ascend: Rising into abyssal open plains from the trenches

descend: Hadalpelagic begins; pressure >600 atm
ascend: Exiting hadalpelagic into abyssal depths

descend: Temperatures level off around 2 °C. Deep water here stays icy and steady
ascend: Temperatures level off around 2 °C. Deep water here stays icy and steady

descend: Deep-sea sediments teem with microbes, even at hadal depths
ascend: Deep-sea sediments teem with microbes, even at hadal depths

descend: Below the CCD. Carbonate dissolves, so sediments turn to abyssal clay
ascend: Below the CCD. Carbonate dissolves, so sediments turn to abyssal clay

descend: You’re diving as deep as Mount Everest is tall (~8,848 m)!
ascend: You're rising through a depth equal to Everest's height inverted

descend: Even here, deep‑sea sediments contain microplastic fibers
ascend: Even here, deep‑sea sediments contain microplastic fibers

descend: Descending through depths first reached by Trieste (~10,911 m)
ascend: Rising through depths first reached by Trieste (~10,911 m)

descend: Approaching the lip of the Challenger Deep. Lowest trench still below
ascend: Ascending past the Challenger Deep’s lip. Its true bottom is even deeper

descend: You’ve reached Earth’s deepest known point, the Challenger Deep (~10,995 m)
Full sunlight zone: tiny plants make most of the ocean’s oxygen here.
ascend: Heading back toward bright, plant‑filled water.

descend: Red light fades first; only blues and greens follow you down.
ascend: Rising where red colors start to glow again.

descend: Sea‑turtles often dive to this depth for tasty jellyfish.
ascend: Turtles and snorkelers meet just above.

descend: Below most surf waves. You now glide in calmer water.
ascend: Surf waves will soon rumble over your head.

descend: Deeper than normal SCUBA lessons. Special training needed now.
ascend: Coming up to the safe limit for hobby divers.

descend: Nitrogen in your blood can feel dizzy at this level.
ascend: Nitrogen narcosis risk drops as you rise.

descend: Many seas have a sharp temperature drop here, called the thermocline.
ascend: Water will warm quickly just above.

descend: Sunlight is only 1 % of the surface here. Plants can’t grow anymore.
ascend: Photosynthesis becomes possible a short swim up.

descend: Pressure is 9 times what you feel on land.
ascend: Pressure is 9 times what you feel on land.

descend: Record breath‑hold dives reach about this deep. Very few people dare.
ascend: You are swimming above the deepest human breath‑hold record.

descend: Leaving the Sun‑lit ‘epipelagic’ layer. Welcome to the twilight zone.
Light here is dim blue; many fish have huge eyes to catch it.
ascend: Big‑eyed fish will fade from view as light grows.

descend: Pressure is 60 times surface weight. Submarines need very strong walls.
ascend: Pressure is 60 times surface weight. Submarines need very strong walls.

descend: Oxygen is lowest here; animals slow their bodies to survive.
ascend: Breathing gets easier for sea life above.

descend: Bits of sinking plankton fall like snow, called ‘marine snow’.
ascend: The snow of dead plankton thins out above.

descend: The sound channel's center. Whale songs can circle the globe from here.
ascend: The sound channel's center. Whale songs can circle the globe from here.

descend: Entering the midnight zone. No sunlight ever reaches this layer.
ascend: A faint glow may greet you as you rise above 1000 m.

descend: Water stays a steady ~2–3 °C. Like a giant, endless fridge.
ascend: Temperature will soon rise above this deep‑sea chill.

descend: Record dives of hunting sperm whales end around 1.4 km.
ascend: Record dives of hunting sperm whales end around 1.4 km.

descend: Diving into Mid‑Atlantic Ridge rift valleys. Ridge crest sits around 2,500 m
ascend: Entering Mid‑Atlantic Ridge terrain. Rugged volcanic valleys lie ahead

descend: Some deep‑sea creatures grow extra large.
ascend: Giant isopods and amphipods will become rarer above.

descend: Water here is super still. Currents slow to a creep.
ascend: Currents pick up speed as you rise.

descend: The water grows corrosive. Carbonate shells begin dissolving in many oceans.
ascend: Tiny shells will stay whole again above around these depths.

descend: In the Atlantic, corrosion becomes so strong here that shells won’t survive.
ascend: In the Atlantic, corrosion becomes so strong here that shells won’t survive.

descend: Hydrothermal vents, underwater geysers, exist down here.
ascend: Hydrothermal vents, underwater geysers, exist down here.

descend: Welcome to the abyssal zone: dark, cold, but full of weird life.
ascend: Welcome to the abyssal zone: dark, cold, but full of weird life.

descend: Some deep‑sea microbes eat oil and gas seeping from the seafloor.
ascend: Oil‑eating microbes become rarer above.

descend: Daily ‘marine snow’ may take a century to settle this far.
ascend: Daily ‘marine snow’ may take a century to settle this far.

descend: Abyssal plains stretch flat like deserts made of mud.
ascend: Leaving the flattest part of Earth’s seafloor behind.

descend: Benthic storms, powerful bottom currents, can still swirl at this depth.
ascend: Benthic storms, powerful bottom currents, swirl at this depth.

descend: Manganese nodules, rocky golf balls rich in metals, dot the floor.
ascend: Manganese nodules, rocky golf balls rich in metals, dot the floor.

descend: Approaching the trench lip; next stop, hadal zone.
ascend: Leaving steep trench walls for flatter abyss.

descend: Entering the hadal zone. Named after Hades, the god of the underworld.
ascend: Climbing out of Hades’ zone back to the abyss.

descend: Trench floor mud is only 1 °C. Close to freezing but never ice.
ascend: Trench floor mud is only 1 °C. Close to freezing but never ice.

descend: Life here survives on tiny bits of food that drift down.
ascend: Life here survives on tiny bits of food that drift down.

descend: Glass sponges have been found perched on trench walls here.
ascend: Glass sponges have been found perched on trench walls here.

descend: Scientists filmed snailfish swimming happily at these depths.
ascend: Scientists filmed snailfish swimming happily at these depths.

descend: Now deeper than Everest is tall. Welcome below the world’s highest mountain flip.
ascend: Now deeper than Everest is tall. Welcome below the world’s highest mountain flip!

descend: Microplastics have been found even in trench cores here.
ascend: Microplastics have been found even in trench cores here.

descend: Very few living cells work this deep; energy is incredibly scarce.
ascend: Very few living cells work this deep; energy is incredibly scarce.

descend: Only a handful of people have ever been this deep!
ascend: Only a handful of people have ever been this deep!

descend: Almost at Challenger Deep, the lowest point on Earth’s surface.
ascend: Leaving Challenger Deep’s doorway behind.

descend: Touchdown: Challenger Deep, ~10 928 m. The ocean’s absolute bottom!
ascend: Ascending from the very deepest known place on the planet.

descend: Below verified charts, this is uncharted imagination land.
ascend: Returning to depths humans have truly measured.
